comments:
With the latest 0419I driver (I've seen this a few times with previous drivers 
as well), I sometimes get this error when doing server stuff (e.g. trying to 
add module to Tomcat 5.0 server, stopping or starting server).  When this 
happens, any server tooling calls takes very long (minutes) to finish.  I've 
also run into an intermitten problem where I would not able to get projectURL 
We are calling ServerUtil.getServersByModule but would get a null back.  Are 
these known problems and is there any known workaround?  I'm using JDK 142_07.

The problem is I don't get this problem every time with a predictable way.  
I'll hit this problem when:

- adding module to server
- stopping and starting server

The scenarios I had tried a lot is to go through bottom-up or top-down Web 
service scenario with Axis on Tomcat 5.  Have Axis deploy failed.  Then clean 
the project, stop the server and restart the server.  After doing this a few 
times with different J2ee Web module, I usually run into this problem and 
starting or stopping the server would take a few minutes.  It usually did 
finish after a while.  There were a couple of times it just hangs there or 
return with error in starting server.

I also got a similar problem when trying to restart a Tomcat 5.0 server which 
already had 3 modules added:

I sometimes also getting this error when trying to getUnderlyingResource from 
the IVirtualResource as in the following:

IVirtualFolder webInfLib = component.getFolder(new Path("/WEB-INF/lib"));
if (webInfLib != null) {
        IVirtualResource[] resources = webInfLib.members();
	IResource aResource = null;
	for (int i = 0; i < resources.length; i++) {
		aResource = resources[i].getUnderlyingResource();
	}
}

I'll take a look at this today...

Please let us know if you have problem reproducing the problem or if you want 
us to turn on any kind of trace to help you debug.  I found that I always run 
into this problem after less than half an hour of running Web services 
scenarios.  This includes the following kinds of activities:
1. Create 2 or 3 J2EE Web modules
2. Create Tomcat 5.0 server
3. Add modules to server
4. Run through Web service bottom-up, top-down or client scenario
5. Stop
6. Run Project->Clean
7. Start server
8. Create more J2EE Web modules either in new projects or in existing projects
9. Repeat step 3 to 7.

When the problem starts to happen, doing anything with server or modules 
(getting list of servers a module is associated with, starting server, stopping 
server) would take a long while (a couple of minutes)to finish.  It usually 
does finish but occasionally just hang or returns with "error in starting 
server" with no trace in the console.

I'm still getting this problem with 0422I 16:01 running in a stand-alone 
Eclipse environment (not in self-hosting).  I'm tried running with Sun JDK 
1.4.2-06 and JDK1.4.2_07 and got the error with both.  I'll try with IBM's JRE 
to see if it makes a difference.  Different people on our team had run into 
this problem many times as well.  We need to address this in M4.

Similar exception in the Web Services Explorer. For this one, J2EE is out of 
the picture. My guess is that we are trying to "compare" a Xerces created node 
with a Crimson created node.

FYI, I posted the following note just now to wtp-dev:

To all, but especially folks most in the know on the nature of WTP's inclusion 
of Xerces, a critical problem exists between Crimson and Xerces that would, in 
my opinion, block M4.

There are two bugs that are making me nervous: 91927 [1] and 92402 [2]. The Web 
Services and J2EE teams are both observing exceptions thrown by the Crimson 
parser very consistently:

org.apache.crimson.tree.DomEx: NOT_FOUND_ERR: That node does not exist in this 
context.
	at org.apache.crimson.tree.ParentNode.replaceChild(ParentNode.java:469)
	...

org.apache.crimson.tree.DomEx: NOT_FOUND_ERR: That node does not exist in this 
context.
	at org.apache.crimson.tree.ParentNode.removeChild(ParentNode.java:500)
	...

In the Web Services case, the Web services wizards and the Web Services 
Explorer are both suffering. Jeff Liu mentioned that changes were made a week 
or two ago to how the Xerces parser was bundled within our stack of plugins and 
to the extent its jars were exported. If memory serves, the above Crimson 
exceptions began showing up around the same time. Jeff theorized that classes 
from Crimson and Xerces were bumping into each other in that infamous manner 
unique to the Eclipse plugin classloading mechanism.

So, I tried two experiments using the Web Services Explorer, one of the 
components getting hammered by the first exception above.

1. Ran Eclipse WTP on Sun's JRE*. The scenario described in 92402 [2] explodes.
2. Ran Eclipse WTP on IBM's JRE**. The scenario described in 92402 [2] works.

The Sun JRE includes Crimson. The IBM JRE includes Xerces. WTP includes Xerces. 
Coincidence? I think not!

We need help working out a solution to this problem. It seems either Xerces 
needs to be isolated into a very small box so that higher order plugins in the 
stack that rely on XML parsing (Crimson) don't know its there, or we need to 
remove our dependency on Xerces once and for all (and I realize this latter 
thought is easier said than done).

* java -version
java version "1.4.2_05"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2_05-b04)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.2_05-b04, mixed mode)

** java -version
java version "1.4.1"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.1)
Classic VM (build 1.4.1, J2RE 1.4.1 IBM Windows 32 build cn1411-20030930 (JIT 
enabled: jitc))

[1] https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=91927
[2] https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=92402

I verified the workaround (java.endorsed.dirs), it works for the Web Services 
Explorer.

I tried setting "java.endorsed.dirs" to the Xerces Jar directory when bringing 
up Eclipse but still get a similar problem when going through Web service 
scenario.  The error is not a DOMException rather than crimson).  Note that the 
problem is still intermitten but seems to occur after a shorting duration of 
testing Web service.  Also, there's a new "Out of Memory" problem and the 
workbench is not usable after this problem occurs.

Jeffrey stopped by a few minutes ago. After a few experiments, he believes the 
out of memory condition is unrelated to the NOT_FOUND_ERR DOMException. By 
increasing the virtual memory limits on the Sun JRE, the out of memory 
condition vanishes, but the DOMException remains.

Created an attachment (id=20327)
Apply this patch to the org.eclipse.wst.common.emf plug-in

I've tested with the 2 patched JARs (workbench.jar and wtpemf.jar) Jeffrey sent 
(built from HEAD+wst.common.emf patch) and tried a few Web services scenarios.  
I am still getting the Crimson error as reported in 91927 after 2 or 3 Web 
services scenarios.  So it does not look like the problem is fixed yet.

Created an attachment (id=20350)
Apply this patch to the org.eclipse.wst.common.emf plug-in

I believe this problem really belongs to "blocking" because I always run into 
this problem after running less than 5 Web services scenarios (bottom-up, top-
down or client).  When this intermitten happens, any calls that involves 
modules (e.g. getting list of servers that has the server install, getting list 
of resources in a module, start server) takes a very long time (minutes) to 
finish or fails all together.  The Web services wizard is not usable after that 
points.  Also, starting and stopping the server using server tooling wizard 
takes very long time to finish or fails.  Some times, the whole hangs.  If I 
stop the workbench and restart, sometimes I can get 1 or 2 more run of the Web 
services scenarios.  A lot of times, I need to start with a new workspace in 
order to have any success with Web services scenarios again.  So, this is very 
unacceptable for the user.

I tried replacing the 2 JARs and started with a new workspace.  I got another 
Crimson error (a slightly different one) after doing the following:

Install server target to Tomcat 5.
Create project a1 and module a1m1.
Create project s1 and module s1m1.
Go through creating bottom-up Web service using the converter.java (similar to 
Web service bottom-up scenario) using a1m1.
Go through creating Web service client using WSDL file generated in bottom-up 
scenario.
When I hit Finish on the proxy page (the last page), I got the following error:
